Notes: ""Primary schools, secondary schools, and universities are permitted to hold in-person classes.? Preschools remain closed.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""Health centers and hospitals are fully operational.  Restaurants are open from 6a.m. to 9p.m. for table service, and from 6a.m. to 10p.m. for takeout.? In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.? Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 10p.m.? Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.    Recreational use of beaches and public swimming pools remains suspended.  Recreational use of boats is permitted, up to 50% of capacity.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.""    ""Individual and group exercise is permitted between the hours of 5a.m. to 9p.m.? Groups exercising together are limited to no more than ten people.? Everyone is encouraged to adhere to social distancing.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""individuals are encouraged to stay at home and practise social distancing""    ""?Groups exercising together are limited to no more than ten people.? Everyone is encouraged to adhere to social distancing.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329182513/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/angola/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
""Is public transportation operating?? Yes   Public transportation is limited to 75 percent capacity.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""Is a curfew in place?? No   The Angolan government recommends staying indoors and away from public areas between the hours of 10p.m. and 5a.m. ""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

""Travel in the country is possible, but requires a rapid COVID-19 test. Air passengers can undertake a rapid COVID-19 test at domestic airports. Test documentation will be checked at all provincial borders. Test results are deemed to be valid for 7 days. Passengers travelling for longer than 7 days will need to undertake further tests as necessary, to continue to move around the country.    The Angolan government has declared a “situation of public calamity” which imposes a number of restrictions and public health measures to limit the spread of the virus:    individuals are encouraged to stay at home and practise social distancing  face masks are compulsory in all areas outside your home or hotel room, including in private motor vehicles. Fines are imposed for non-compliance  restrictions are in place on travel into and out of Luanda province and the neighbouring province of Kwanza Norte""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329182513/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/angola/coronavirus

""The Angolan government has instituted mandatory home quarantine for anyone entering the country, regardless of citizenship.? Government regulations require arriving passengers to re-test seven days after arrival and be released by the health authorities in order to leave quarantine.? For those unable to quarantine at home, or for those who test positive upon arrival, the Government of Angola has set up multiple quarantine sites throughout the country, including two quarantine sites just outside of the capital city of Luanda.  Asymptomatic COVID patients may be allowed to isolate at home.? Anyone with symptoms, anyone considered vulnerable, or?anyone?who is not able to isolate appropriately in their home will be required to go into a government-run health center.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No income support    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155246/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

""The use of a face mask is required in all public areas, including anytime you leave your house or hotel room, while using public transport, and in all establishments.  Face masks are not required if you are operating a vehicle alone or exercising outside.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155758/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

With this first batch of vaccines, estimated at about 10 per cent of the country's first phase vaccine needs, the Government will immunize health professionals, vulnerable people and those with complicated comorbidities.  So we have key workers in terms of health professionals, vulnerable people and those with complicated comorbidities receiving the vaccine. And the vaccine being delivered is the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine.    ""while in Angola, vaccines have reached over 49 000 people, including more than 28 000 health workers in the past week.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329190357/https://www.afro.who.int/news/angola-becomes-first-country-eastern-and-southern-africa-region-receive-covax-vaccines-0  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405164153/https://www.afro.who.int/news/africas-covid-19-vaccination-gains-pace-nearly-7-million-doses-given

There is a public guarantee plan and credit lines for refinancing measures as well.    -------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Same policy appears to be in place, there is support for both formal and informal vulnerable households.  ------------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The IMF highlights support for vulnerable households through:     These measures comprise (i) a health preparedness and response plan for 2020 (0.9 percent of GDP) and 2021 (0.7 percent of GDP), and (ii) a socio-economic response plan to support formal sector companies (0.9 percent of GDP) and vulnerable households—for the latter, through cash transfers, electricity and water bills subsidies, and urgent social projects (0.2 percent of GDP). In addition, a public guarantee plan (1.0 percent of GDP) and credit lines and refinancing measures (0.7 percent of GDP) were established to foster access to finance for micro, small, and medium enterprises.    see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425104021/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Per IMF site there continues to be support for companies both formally and informally.  Currently there are established avenues to gain access to financial help for micro, small and medium enterprises.  There is a public guarantee plan and credit lines for refinancing measures as well.    -------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411013810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The same support appears to be available to both individuals and businesses.    ----------------------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

As of June 3, 2020, the Government of Burkina Faso cancelled the curfew which was in effect throughout the country, except for the provinces that are under state of emergency (the East and Sahel regions, Kossi and Sourou provinces in Boucle de Mouhoun, Kenedougou province in Hauts Bassins, Louroum province in the North, and Koulpelogo province in the Center-East region).    see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409153614/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  See here: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409154030/https://www.gouvernement.gov.bf/informations/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=522&cHash=00653664cebb25b57994f7e99c981303

While there is data that indicates there is a budget to support, it does not indicate the level of income support for individual workers. It appears to be more aimed at businesses.     The IMF has updates on fiscal, monetary, and macro financial policy that aims to help those struggling due to the pandemic. It is valid from April 2 2021 and this includes a partial guarantee fund, which the government expects to leverage to help the financial sector inject fresh credit into the economy during 2020-2021 in support of private businesses in hard-hit sectors.    see more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409163906/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Several measures have been taken under the revised budget, including: (i) lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses; (ii) lowering other selected tax rates; (iii) delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties; (iv) suspending government fees charged on informal sector operators for rent, security and parking in urban markets; (v) lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sectors; (vi) suspending on-site tax inspection operations; (vii) Donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses; (viii) supporting the water and electricity bills, including through cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups; and (ix) securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.    see more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409163906/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Botswana received a consignment of the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority.     See the vaccine self-registration portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090433/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    See also an earlier government press release about the consignment in early March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330091016/https://twitter.com/bwgovernment/status/1369215961308553219    Refer to the facebook page of the Ministry of Health for more details:  https://archive.vn/6NBHY

Botswana received its first consignment of 33,600 AstraZeneca vaccines from the COVAX facility. This is the second consignment since receiving the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page also announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority.     See the vaccine self-registration portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090433/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    See also an earlier government press release about the consignment in early March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330091016/https://twitter.com/bwgovernment/status/1369215961308553219    Refer to the facebook page of the Ministry of Health for more details:  https://archive.vn/6NBHY

Botswana received vaccines on the 28th of March. Both AstraZeneca and SK Bioscience are mentioned in the sources.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144939/https://www.gavi.org/covax-vaccine-roll-out/botswana    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405145046/https://www.afro.who.int/news/new-dawn-botswanas-covid-19-response    Currently only people under B and C are eligible to receive vaccinations, but could not find government sources to corroborate this.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405145331/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/27/botswana-receives-over-33000-doses-of-covid-19-vaccines/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090853/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-03/26/c_139838942.htm

Botswana is administering mainly AstraZeneca vaccines and has done so since the end of March. A 6 April press release stated the need to protect the most vulnerable, and thus a decision has been made to prioritise the elderly above the age of 75.      See the press release:   https://archive.vn/VfzZo

Botswana is administering mainly AstraZeneca vaccines and has done so since the end of March. A 6 April press release stated the need to protect the most vulnerable, and thus a decision has been made to prioritise the elderly above the age of 75. (Group C only).    The vaccine rollout programme has halted in some areas, as announced on the official twitter, since the vaccine doses allocated to these areas were finished. Vaccination policy will only resume in these areas when the next consignment arrives, which the announcement says is in the following weeks. Other areas continue to administer their allocated vaccines.     See the announcement   https://archive.vn/ah205

An aggressive contact-tracing regime has been central to many African countries’ achievements in slowing the spread of Covid-19. Drawing on experience responding to previous disease outbreaks and extensive networks of community health workers, among other assets, countries have been able to lean on robust tracing regimes and stringent isolation policies to control transmission despite limitations in testing. Important lessons on contact tracing can be learned from effective strategies deployed in Africa, especially as governments around the world seek to loosen mobility restrictions and safely reopen their economies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404074735/https://institute.global/advisory/insights-africas-covid-19-response-contact-tracing    One difficulty lies in the multitude of villages to be served, and there is still a lack of mobile oxygen units, respirators as well as training in contact-tracing techniques. Once again, civil society seeks national and international solidarity from donors, companies and international organisations and institutions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404074822/https://www.fern.org/publications-insight/covid-19-in-the-central-african-republic-civil-societys-response-to-the-pandemic-2212/

Country-Specific Information:    There is a nationwide curfew in the DRC each evening from 9 pm to 5 am. Masks are required in public spaces.  Businesses, schools, airports, and ports are open.  While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412190635/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Country-Specific Information:    The Republic of Congo has confirmed cases of COVID-19 since March 14, 2020. As of March 31, there were 10,084 confirmed cases, 9,286 recoveries and 137 confirmed deaths.  The government of The Republic of Congo extended a State of Health Emergency until May 4 to limit the spread of COVID-19. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire is from 23:00 until 05:00, Mondays through Fridays and from 20:00 until 05:00 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.  The Congolese air borders opened on August 24 for international flights. International air carriers are resuming some services into and from Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.  Land and river borders remain closed.  Places of worship, schools, restaurants and bars are open.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185611/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Country-Specific Information:    The Republic of Congo has confirmed cases of COVID-19 since March 14, 2020. As of March 31, there were 10,084 confirmed cases, 9,286 recoveries and 137 confirmed deaths.  The government of The Republic of Congo extended a State of Health Emergency until May 4 to limit the spread of COVID-19. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire is from 23:00 until 05:00, Mondays through Fridays and from 20:00 until 05:00 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.  The Congolese air borders opened on August 24 for international flights. International air carriers are resuming some services into and from Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.  Land and river borders remain closed.  Places of worship, schools, restaurants and bars are open.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185611/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412184316/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

Domestic Restrictions:    Gatherings of more than three people in public and private spaces are prohibited during the state of health emergency.    Marketplaces may open five days a week in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.    In Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire, a curfew is in effect 23:00-05:00 Monday to Friday and 20:00-05:00 Saturday to Sunday. There is no curfew in the rest of the country.    Restaurants and bars can reopen but measures must be taken to accommodate customers in outside areas if possible.    Security personnel have increased screening measures, which will be conducted throughout the country's entry and exit points.    The wearing of facemasks is mandatory in public spaces.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419183227/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/467301/congo-covid-19-related-state-of-health-emergency-extended-for-20-days-from-april-17-update-22

Country-Specific Information:    The Republic of Congo has confirmed cases of COVID-19 since March 14, 2020. As of March 31, there were 10,084 confirmed cases, 9,286 recoveries and 137 confirmed deaths.  The government of The Republic of Congo extended a State of Health Emergency until May 4 to limit the spread of COVID-19. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire is from 23:00 until 05:00, Mondays through Fridays and from 20:00 until 05:00 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.  The Congolese air borders opened on August 24 for international flights. International air carriers are resuming some services into and from Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.  Land and river borders remain closed.  Places of worship, schools, restaurants and bars are open.  All international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185611/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412184316/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419190043/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to the Republic of Congo  All passengers arriving in the Republic of Congo by commercial flights should provide proof of a negative coronavirus (COVID-19) test undertaken within 72 hours upon entry, with the exception of children under 11 years of age. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Passengers who do not present a negative COVID-19 test upon entry will undertake a COVID-19 test at the airport, and need to self-isolate for 14 days, pending the results.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Screening on arrival  Travellers entering the Republic of Congo may be subject to screening, including temperature checks.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191323/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/entry-requirements

International Travel    Land and river borders are closed. Air travel has resumed.    International travelers must present a negative COVID-19 test no older than 72 hours on arrival. Persons arriving with a negative test will still be subject to a 14-day self-isolation period at their residence or hotel. Self-isolation is also required for travelers in transit.    Persons arriving with a test result older than 72 hours or without a test certificate will be subject to a test upon arrival at their own expense, followed by a 14-day self-isolation period at their residence or hotel.    Only travelers over the age of 10 are subject to tests.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419183227/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/467301/congo-covid-19-related-state-of-health-emergency-extended-for-20-days-from-april-17-update-22

No change in policy.    All islands remain under a State of Contingency where restrictions remain in place on businesses, public gatherings as well as restaurant operations.    Religious activities will be allowed with limited capacity with the condition that social distancing protocols are maintained.    At funerals, a maximum of 20 people may attend.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

Updating indicator as 10 is included in code 4, not code 3.    Gatherings at private events should not exceed more than ten people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

No change in policy.    It is mandatory to wear a non-surgical mask when using public transport in Cape Verde and when accessing ports and airports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

No change in policy.    All islands remain under State of Contingency where restrictions remain in place on businesses, public gatherings as well as restaurant operations.    There is no curfew in place at this time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

No change in policy.    Domestic travel among the islands is allowed.    Internal inter-island flights and passenger ferries are operational. Those travelling between islands will need to complete an online health surveillance form and present a COVID-19 (rapid antigen test) done in the last 72 hours before travel from some of the islands.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

No change in policy.    Maritime borders are open.    Cruise ships and other boats are allowed to dock at the entry ports.    Citizens and residents are allowed to enter.    Foreigners, including tourists, are allowed to enter.    All arrivals will have their temperature scanned at the entry ports. Travellers recording a high temperature may undergo a COVID-19 test on arrival.    To enter Cape Verde, travellers must have a negative COVID-19 Antigen or RT-PCR test certificate issued within the 72 hours prior to departure. Children under seven years of age are exempt from this requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

No change in policy.    For the most vulnerable, mitigating measures are estimated at CVE 2.2 billion (1.2 percent of GDP). They comprise: (i) income compensation to provide financial support to individuals operating in the informal sector; (ii) social inclusion emergency measures for vulnerable people without income; (iii) social inclusion income, with support from the World Bank ; (iv) support to microfinance institutions to support interest-free loans to vulnerable households and; (v) care for the elderly with food assistance and other financial support.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405151544/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy.    On April 1, 2020, the authorities introduced a moratorium on insurance payments and loans repayment during April-September 2020 for household, companies, and non-profit associations, as well as the SMEs. The moratorium on loan repayment was extended to December 31, 2020 and will now remain in place until the end of the third quarter of 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405151544/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405153939/https://covid19.cv/

Updating indicator back to code 3; please review previous code.    Citizens requiring a COVID-19 PCR-RT test for international travel should contact their nearest health delegation. The cost for the PCR-RT test is 6,500 CVE (approximately $70).    Citizens requiring a rapid test for inter-island travel should contact their nearest health delegation or a private lab.  The cost for a rapid test is generally less than 2,000 CVE (approximately $22).    Results are generally provided via phone call. Travelers can choose to receive their results via email or by picking up a hard copy of the test results.    Effective 15 December 2021, the Government of Cabo Verde has authorized the use of antigen tests (Ag-RDT) to detect COVID-19 prior to travel.  Travelers entering Cabo Verde?must?present results of?a negative COVID-19 PCR-RT test or an antigen test (Ag-RDT, commonly known as a “rapid test”) administered no more than 72 hours prior to?flight departure?to?gain entry?to Cabo Verde. Children under age seven are exempt?from presenting test results?to gain?entry?to Cabo Verde.?  PCR test results are still required to transit Lisbon and the Azores.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155015/https://cv.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.    Upon arrival in Cabo Verde, travelers will have their temperature checked and must submit a completed health questionnaire. Anyone displaying symptoms such as fever may be put in isolation and subjected to a COVID-19 test on arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155015/https://cv.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.    The use of face masks is mandatory for all individuals in public places. Children under the age of ten and individuals with health conditions that prevent them from wearing face-covering are exempt from the requirement. Individuals who are exercising and able to observe social distancing are also exempt from the requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

For this first phase of vaccination, some groups of people were prioritized taking into account the risk of developing serious disease that can cause even death and professional groups that are on the front line of combating the pandemic. Thus, the priority groups to be vaccinated in this first phase are health professionals; chronic patients (hypertensive and diabetic); population over 60 years of age; hotel professionals and related to tourism; professionals from ports and airports; teachers and support staff in schools; police; armed forces; and civil protection professionals and firefighters.    So far the country has received two types of vaccines, bewith achstraZeneca and the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. Meanwhile, the country may receive other vaccines, with the support of the World Bank.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155801/https://covid19.cv/vacinas/

No change; no explicit policy addressing the protection of elderly people in Cabo Verde. Coding indicator in line with C6.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331024041/https://www.covidchecker.com/en/

According to the US Embassy in Eritrea, University and SAWA students can attend training and classes. All other students are to remain at home.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411211513/https://er.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the US Embassy in Eritrea, Government offices have closed or suspended many routine services, and restrictions are in place throughout the country to prevent the spread of COVID-19.  Essential businesses (e.g., grocery stores) are open until 8PM.  Restaurants, entertainment venues, and religious services remain closed.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411211513/https://er.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Enhanced screening protocols are in place:   All arriving and departing travellers must present the results of a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test.  Arriving passengers:  testing must be completed no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Guinea or the traveler will be tested upon arrival and be required to quarantine for 14 days.  Arriving passengers with proof of a negative test within the 72 hours prior to arrival will not undergo any additional testing or quarantine in Guinea.  Arriving passengers with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment center until two negative tests are completed. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420020132/https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

All travellers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified may be required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival. Travellers must also comply with the current requirement to possess a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival into The Gambia. Individuals arriving without a negative test that complies with this requirement, or who tests positive for COVID-19 upon arrival, will be required to undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveler’s own expense. Quarantined individuals should expect to be tested for COVID-19 by Gambian Health Officials upon arrival at quarantine facilities. Quarantined individuals should expect to stay up to 14 days in a quarantine facility, depending on their test results. Quarantined individuals are required to pay all costs associated with this quarantine period, and may also be expected to pay for any necessary COVID-19 tests. Those held at quarantine facilities are provided with basic shelter, food, water, and medical care.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329222209/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 testing can be done at the Medical Research Council (MRC) in Fajara, or at several Gambian government-run testing facilities at Independence Stadium, Bakau, KMC and Brusubi Main Roundabout, adjacent to Petroleum House, WCR. Testing is typically available at the Gambian government-run sites Monday-Friday, and costs 3,000 dalasi. Cost and testing schedule at MRC may fluctuate. Note that medical resources in The Gambia are limited.  Tests results are generally provided by physical copy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405120245/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Due to a new of Covid cases in the country, a suspension of face-to-face learning in late March 2021 and early April 2021 at all institutions across the country were asked to close. However, examinations were still allowed and medical students were allowed to continue on.  ______________________________    Quote (1):  ""Kenya has suspended face-to-face learning in all educational institutions, including universities and tertiary and vocational colleges, except for students sitting for their examinations and those in medical training institutions."" According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, all passengers coming to Kenya from the UK require a valid COVID-19 vaccination certificate and a COVID-19 negative PCR test and must self-isolate on arrival for 7 days. All UK citizens and residents travelling to Kenya from the UK via any route who have a valid COVID-19 PCR test, but do not have a valid COVID-19 vaccination certificate, will be subject to 14 days mandatory quarantine on arrival at a Government of Kenya facility at their own cost. All travellers under the age of 18 will only require a certificate of COVID-19 negative PCR test to enter Kenya. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411183025/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/entry-requirements
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210420071518/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus

Quote (1):  ""Kenya also has existing cash transfer programs targeting over a million people, that receive 2,000 Kenyan shillings, or $19, per month. The national treasury allocated an additional 10 billion shillings to this program for supporting vulnerable groups including the elderly and orphans during this pandemic period.""    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20210426145243/https://www.devex.com/news/cash-transfers-lead-the-social-assistance-response-to-covid-19-96949  _______________    Quote (2):  ""The government’s COVID-19 Emergency Fund has raised more than KES 1 billion ($9 million), some of which will be sent as weekly stipends to low-income households in urban areas. ""    ""Still, the investment Kenya has made in its G2P payment infrastructure is already proving critical to mitigating the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on Kenya’s most vulnerable people. In April, the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection released four months’ worth of payments to current recipients, plus KES 500 million ($4.7 million) in arrears to people with severe disabilities.""    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20210426145324/https://www.cgap.org/blog/kenyas-expansion-g2p-becomes-lifeline-during-covid-19-crisis  _______________    Quote (3):  ""The government, as part of the FY2019/20 budget (ending June 30, 2020), initially earmarked Ksh40 billion (0.4 percent of GDP) for Covid-related expenditure, including health sector (enhanced surveillance, laboratory services, isolation units, equipment, supplies, and communication); social protection (cash transfers and food relief); and funds for expediting payments of existing obligations to maintain cash flow for businesses during the crisis. The FY2020/21 budget includes a Ksh56.6 million (0.5 percent of GDP) economic stimulus package that includes a new youth employment scheme, provision of credit guarantees, fast-tracking payment of VAT refunds and other government obligations, increased funding for cash transfers, and several other initiatives. A package of tax measures has been adopted, including full income tax relief for persons earning below the equivalent of $225 per month, reduction of the top pay-as you earn rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the base corporate income tax rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the turnover tax rate on small businesses from 3 to 1 percent, and a reduction of the standard VAT rate from 16 to 14 percent. Some of the tax measures, including the reduction of top PAYE rate, corporate income tax rate and VAT were reversed effective January 1, 2021.""    Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20210424041427/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#S

This was revealed during a parliamentary inquiry, where the Cabinet Secretary for Health, Mutahi Kagwe, explained that the initial digital surveillance system was overwhelmed with increasing cases which were spread out in various parts of the country. The country had therefore upgraded its system to include laboratory orders, facilitate contract tracing , manage patients in quarantine and generate reports."" ""    Link (4): http://archive.today/2021.04.25-154424/https://www.who.int/news-room/feature-stories/detail/scaling-up-contract-tracing-to-combat-covid-19-in-kenya

A,C - Key workers, Elderly Groups  Astra Zeneca    ***Discussion to acquire the Pfizer and Johnson&Johnson vaccines are underway***    The vaccine is first being rolled out to key workers, with the addition of the diplomatic community receiving doses as well.  There is evidence that there were changes to the initial plan within the first few weeks of the campaign rollout to also include the elderly in the first phase.    As the coding only requires to fo focus on the 3 groups, only ""2 groups"" were chosen based on the available options.  _________________      Quote (1):  ""Kenya’s Ministry of Health has already launched its campaign and kicked off its deployment plan for the vaccines which are prioritized for frontline health workers and essential staff including security personnel.""    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425160440/https://www.afro.who.int/news/kenya-receives-covid-19-vaccines-and-launches-landmark-national-campaign  __________________    Quote (2):  ""The plan outlined by the Ministry of Health involved three phases, the last two of which were to run concurrently. In phase one, between February and June 2021, 1.25 million health workers, security and immigration officials would be vaccinated. In phases two and three, from July 2021 to June 2022, nearly 10 million over-50s and over-18s with underlying health conditions and five million of those considered vulnerable, such as those in informal settlements, would be immunised.""    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425161648/https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2021/4/3/what-is-going-wrong-with-kenyas-covid-19-vaccine-drive  __________________    Quote (3):  ""NAIROBI (Reuters) - Kenya has offered free COVID-19 vaccines to all diplomats based there, including thousands of United Nations staff, even though it has not completed inoculating its own health workers, other frontline staff or elderly, drawing criticism from local medics.""    Link (3): http://archive.today/2021.04.25-161314/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-kenya-idUSKBN2BC0LH  _________________    Quote (4):  ""Kenya’s first phase is meant to run until the end of June 2021. The initial plan was to vaccinate high priority groups, such as frontline healthcare workers. A few weeks into the rollout, the target group was expanded to include all Kenyans older than 58 years. This expanded the original target from 1.25 million people to about 3.2 million in the same time period.""    Link (4): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425162601/https://theconversation.com/kenyas-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-has-got-off-to-a-slow-start-the-gaps-and-how-to-fix-them-158477  _________________    Quote (5):  ""Kenya’s ministry of health on Monday announced that it will starting immediately prioritize persons aged above 58 years in the ongoing COVID-19 mass vaccination drive.""    Link (5): http://archive.today/2021.04.25-162808/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/25/kenya-to-prioritize-persons-aged-over-58-years-in-vaccination-drive/  _________________    Quote (6):  ""Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe has said  the government was pursuing acquisition of one million doses of  vaccines each from  Pfizer as well as Johnson and Johnson respectively to supplement the Astrazeneca vaccines.""    Link (6): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425161512/https://www.health.go.ke/kenya-to-acquire-pfizer-johnson-and-johnson-vaccines-says-cs-kagwe/

A negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) isn’t required to enter the country. Health screening procedures are conducted at airports. Travellers will be tested for COVID-19 upon arrival at the traveller’s expense (75 $). Incoming travellers will have a mandatory temperature check. All passengers are required to wear a face mask and wash their hands.   Travellers who test positive for COVID-19 upon arrival will undergo treatment based on Liberia’s case management guidelines.  Travellers who test negative should self-quarantine for seven days and monitor their symptoms for a period of 14 days, beginning the day after arrival in Liberia.     https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://lr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

After receipt of 96,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, through the COVAX facility, Liberia, on April 1, 2021, joined many countries to officially launch the vaccination campaign against COVID-19. Vaccines are available to the frontline workers and the most vulnerable (A and B groups).  The vaccines are now deployed at eight sites in Montserrado and Margibi counties including; the Number 14 Military hospital, JFK memorial hospital, Catholic hospital, Redemption and SOS Hospitals among others. The vaccines will subsequently be rolled out to the others counties in the coming days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210409171516/https://www.afro.who.int/news/liberia-launches-vaccination-against-covid-19

Astrazeneca  A,B  After receipt of 96,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, through the COVAX facility, Liberia, on 1st April 2021, joined many countries to officially launch the vaccination campaign against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.afro.who.int/news/liberia-launches-vaccination-against-covid-19   Vaccines are available to the frontline workers and the most vulnerable (A and B groups). The vaccines are now deployed at eight sites in Montserrado and Margibi counties including; the Number 14 Military hospital, JFK memorial hospital, Catholic hospital, Redemption and SOS Hospitals among others. The vaccines will subsequently be rolled out to the others counties in the coming days.  Liberia has identified its 20 per cent priority population to be targeted. The priority group includes health care workers, elderly people (60+), people with co-morbidities, refugees and other essential workers who cannot social distance due to the work they performed.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/liberia/press-releases/ministry-health-starts-vaccination-campaign-against-covid19-0

On 3 April 2021, the Government of Madagascar declared a national Health State of Emergency, for an initial period of 15 days. Business opening hours and public transport operations are subject to change at short notice, and some venues remain closed or operate with limited capacity. A curfew from 9pm to 4am is in place in the regions of Analamanga (including the capital Antananarivo), Antsinana, Boeny, Nosy Be and Sava.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419164438/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus

Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people. Health minister Fanta Siby said that the vaccination would first target medical staff, the elderly and those with co-morbidities. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406040809/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/22/mali-picks-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-to-begin-vaccination-april//

The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is available through the COVAX Facility and according to the Malian Minister of Health, vaccines are initially being given to health personnel, people over 60 years of age, and people living with chronic diseases. https://web.archive.org/web/20210417161105/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Government of Mozambique does not require a COVID-19 test to exit the country. However, acting as agents for the airlines, officials at the airport will request a negative COVID-19 PCR test before permitting you through immigration.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Ministry of Health (MISAU) continues screening at airports and other points of entry scanning the temperatures of all travelers.  Passengers who test positive upon arrival in the country or fail to provide a negative test result must self-quarantine for 14 days. Those who provide a negative test result are exempt from the quarantine regulation.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165338/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466831/mozambique-authorities-maintain-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-april-14-update-13  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165431/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Authorities in Mauritania have revised the ongoing nightly curfew as part of the government's efforts to curb the spread of COVID-19. The measure will be in effect 02:00-06:00 during the holy month of Ramadan, through May 13. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420023110/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/465406/mauritania-authorities-amend-curfew-hours-to-0200-0600-through-may-13-update-18

Enhanced screening measures are in place:   The requirement is that all travellers have a negative PCR or negative antigen test within five days prior to arrival in Mauritania.  Mauritanian medical staff take temperatures via thermal camera at all ports of entry. If a traveller has a fever, that traveller will immediately take either a PCR or antigenic test to determine if the person has a COVID infection. Furthermore, all passengers, regardless of nationality, over the age of 11 must have a negative COVID test prior to exiting Mauritania.  All travellers, regardless of nationality, will be required to self-isolate for ten days after arrival in Mauritania. If a traveler tests positive for COVID at the port of entry, that traveller will be quarantined for ten days under Mauritanian government supervision. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420022656/https://mr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Mauritania began its COVID-19 vaccination campaign in late March as a shipment of 50,000 doses arrived from China.    President Mohamed Ould Ghazouani supervised the process, which took place in the National Hospital Centre in the capital Nouakchott.    According to the country's state news agency, Nouakchott's medical staff will get the jabs first, followed by medical staff in all other cities and people with chronic diseases and vulnerable groups. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406043506/https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20210326-mauritania-begins-covid-vaccine-campaign/

""The 9pm to 5am curfew remains in place causing closures for some categories of workers. """"All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures. Wearing of face masks in all public places is mandatory, and those who do not follow these guidelines may face fines."""" The President made a statement on March 29 urging the public to uphold measures through the Easter holidays hinting at easing restrictions if the national positivity rate remains under 5%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404214940/https://www.nyasatimes.com/chakwera-hints-on-easing-covid-19-restrictions/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210403204602/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

All activities that involve an audience, such as music shows, sports, arts, and religious gatherings, are restricted to 50 people or fewer.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210427145954/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi/coronavirus

""Public events continue to be allowed to take place with hygiene measures in place. According to a post from the Minister of Health, public events are currently acting as super spreaders of COVID-19 in Malawi, he urges people to avoid mass gatherings.  April 3, Ministry of Health Facebook post:  """"Today, let me emphasise on the need to adjust our way of life in order to curb the spread of COVID-19 . Mass gatherings including markets, public transport, workplaces, bars, family gatherings, group sports, churches and funeral ceremonies are acting as super spreaders of the disease. I should point it out that the more people interact and the longer the interaction lasts, the higher the risk of spreading COVID-19. The higher the level of community transmission in an area, the higher the risk of spreading  COVID-19. Since we are still experiencing community transmission the risk of COVID-19 rapidly spreading is very high.  This is the time for us to seriously consider re-strategizing our day to day lives and only make decisions that help to reduce the spread of the virus in our midst.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404172652/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3743394329049388%3F__tn__%3DK-R

The policy for public events remains the same. """"All activities that involve an audience, such as music shows, sports, arts, and religious gatherings, are restricted to 50 people or fewer.  All buildings used by the public, whether for business or public service, must be disinfected no less than once a week, and must be fitted with handwashing facilities at the entrance and exits. A curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am. All markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures. Wearing of face masks in all public places is mandatory, and those who do not follow these guidelines may face fines.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410193612/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

""A negative COVID test is required upon entry from all travelers. """"If you’re eligible for entry, you will need to provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken within 10 days of arrival. You may also be tested for COVID-19 on arrival at your own expense. Passengers may be required to remain at the airport or a testing centre until their COVID-19 test results are known, usually within 24 hours.""""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192308/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi/entry-requirements    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192731/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Screening continues to be the policy for international travelers. """"All arriving passengers via air into the Republic of Malawi shall be required to produce a negative SARS Cov-2 PCR test certificate obtained within 10 days prior to arrival in Malawi. Any passenger without the said certificate will be denied entry. All arriving passengers will be asked to self-monitor for l4 days after which they will be followed up by Health Authorities. Arriving passengers may be required to provide samples for Covid-19 testing. Samples will be collected at the airport and test results will be communicated to the concerned within 48 hours.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410193612/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410230839/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi/entry-requirements

All land borders remain closed except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances. Malawians and residents can return to Malawi upon production of an original certified negative COVID-19 test result. Foreigners may not travel to Malawi via land borders. https://archive.vn/lUzXo#selection-2171.2-2171.290  International Flights are operating - Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes https://archive.vn/lUzXo#selection-2439.0-2441.3

Due to increasing numbers of COVID-19 cases recorded in Malawi, and the emergence of a new strain of the virus, Malawi has closed its land borders to all foreigners until further notice. Malawi airspace remains open to a limited number of commercial flights.   All land borders remain closed except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances. Malawians and residents can return to Malawi upon production of an original certified negative COVID-19 test result. Foreigners may not travel to Malawi via land borders.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210427145807/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

""The maize subsidy policy remains in place. Organizations such as FAO and the Famine Early Warning System Network continuously monitor staple food prices and trends in Malawi's agriculture. According to FAO """"The drop in maize prices follows continued availability of affordable maize in ADMARC markets as well as availability of cheaper maize from early harvests in some markets across the country.""""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404213227/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/malawi-covid-19-rapid-response-emergency-agriculture-surveillance-ema-fss-february    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404213536/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/malawi-price-bulletin-march-2021

There is no evidence of the maize subsidies ending. A recent news article reported that the public had requested for a decrease in VAT (Value Added Tax) on cooking oil but the government ruled this out. It will be good to track developments in this for any changes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411210047/https://reliefweb.int/report/malawi/malawi-key-message-update-staple-maize-grain-prices-decrease-atypically-during-peak    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411221605/https://www.nyasatimes.com/govt-rules-out-bringing-down-cooking-oil-tax/

The Ministry of Health continues to urge people who have COVID-19 symptoms to get tested. Some testing is also available to travelers at the airport.  See statement from the Ministry of Health:""""Let me emphasize that, it is important to report for medical screening when one shows any COVID-19 symptoms . The most common symptoms include fever, dry cough, and tiredness, while some patients will present with aches and pains, sore throat, diarrhoea, conjunctivitis, headache, loss of taste or smell, rash on skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes. When one experiences these symptoms, there is need to have a COVID-19 test. The following serious symptoms; difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, loss of speech or movement, require immediate medical attention . This will help us to identify the disease in early stages so that appropriate care is given as soon as possible. ""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404215519/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3746395888749232%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192731/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Testing continues to be generally available to individuals showing COVID-19 symptoms and travelers.   April 11 update from the Ministry of Health: """"As we are still experiencing community transmission of COVID-19, I would like to remind the public on COVID-19 symptoms to facilitate early care seeking when we experience the symptoms. It has to be noted that COVID-19 affects people in different ways. Most infected people will develop mild to moderate illness and recover without hospitalization. The most common symptoms include fever, dry cough, and tiredness, while in some patients it presents with aches and pains, sore throat, diarrhoea, conjunctivitis, headache, loss of taste or smell, rash on the skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes. When one has these symptoms, there is need to have a COVID-19 test. If one experiences serious symptoms such as difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, loss of speech or movement, immediate medical attention is needed. It is important to note that early care seeking leads to positive treatment outcomes.""""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411211250/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3766211166767704%3F__tn__%3DK-R

""A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. The government announced on March 29 that pregnant women are eligible for the vaccine. As of April 4, the government reports 157,581 distributed doses of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine. Local news reported that the """"government has ordered medical personnel to expedite the process of the Covid 19 vaccine in vaccination centres. It follows observations that the vaccination exercise is not starting at the set time of 8am in most centres due to delayed delivery of the vaccines. This has led to crowding and long queues, thereby raising security concerns and frustrating some people to get the vaccine. Currently, the vaccination exercise targets the elderly, people with underlying conditions, journalists and other social workers.""""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404221016/https://www.nyasatimes.com/over-90-000-get-astrazeneca-jab-in-malawi/    April 4, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210404220051/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3746395888749232    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404215205/https://www.nyasatimes.com/govt-says-pregnant-women-can-now-get-vaccine/""

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. """"Currently, we are using the AstraZeneca vaccine and to get fully protected one is required to receive two doses at an interval of 8-12 weeks apart. Those that have received the first dose are encouraged to check on the vaccination card to see when their next dose is due.For those eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in the first phase i.e. the health workers, other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, please take note that the vaccination exercise is still in progress in all Government and CHAM facilities. Please take this opportunity to get vaccinated.""""    April 5, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412001337/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3748838631838291

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  On April 6, the government announced that the vaccine is now available to everyone 18 years old and above. ""I would like to inform the general public that we are now entering the second phase of COVID-19 vaccination whereby apart from those targeted in the first phase i.e. the health workers and other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, the vaccination has been extended to everyone aged 18 years and above. My special appeal goes to those who by nature of their occupation interact with a lot of people on daily basis such as those working in banks, shops, vendors and those in the transport sector to come and get the vaccine. I would like to request everyone aged 18 years and above to utilize this opportunity to get vaccinated so that they are protected from COVID-19 severe disease, risk of hospitalization or death due to COVID-19. The vaccination exercise continues in all the Government and CHAM health facilities.""    April 6, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412000519/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3752144994840988    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411234712/https://www.nyasatimes.com/ministry-of-health-overwhelmed-with-turn-up-for-covid-19-vaccine/

Schools are open but must adhere to the measures to combat, prevent and suppress the spread of COVID-19 at all times. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April, but with no changes for schools closing. Children aged 0 to 5 exempt from wearing masks in schools.    See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

UNESCO reports all schools fully open: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411131251/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse  It is not mandatory for children ages 0 to 5 years to wear masks at school: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411135332/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All businesses, operations and activities may operate and be conducted during their normal times of operation, subject to COVID-19 prevention measures. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April, but with no changes for workplaces closing.    See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

•	Grocery stores remain well-stocked.  •	Sale of alcohol for on-site consumption (shebeens, bars, nightclubs, gambling houses, casinos and restaurants) is allowed from 9:00 am to 10:00 pm, Mondays to Saturdays.  No sale of alcohol is allowed on Sundays and Public Holidays. From February 25th, liquor may be sold to and purchased on Sundays and public holidays by guests booked in or staying at establishments such as hotels, guesthouses, bed and breakfast facilities and casinos.  •	Salons, beauty parlours, hairdressers, pools, spas, gyms, studios, and fitness canters shall practice public health measures. Both the service providers and clients must wear masks, sanitize, and maintain social distancing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210411135332/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public events not cancelled, but with social distancing requirements, 100 person limits and registers to record attendants in place. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April.    See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

•	Limit public gatherings to 100 persons. Registers of attendees must be maintained, temperature checks recorded, and hand sanitising facilities put in place. Face masks and social distancing of at least 2 metres are mandatory  •	Spectators are not allowed at sporting events  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411133607/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

Limit to number of persons in public gatherings increases from 50 to 100, indoors and outdoors. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April. Foreign travellers require a negative PCR Covid Test within 7 days of departure to enter Namibia. Frequent travellers returning within three days after their departure from Namibia are allowed to re-enter the country using their test result used on departure. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April.    See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

Any person entering Namibia must present proof on arrival in Namibia of a negative COVID-19 test taken in the country of departure. The test result must not be older than 7 days (or 168 hours) at the time of entry into Namibia. This requirement also applies to anyone who has been vaccinated against COVID-19 – a negative test must still be produced before entry into the country.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411144730/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/entry-requirements

If a person is confirmed as having tested positive for COVID-19, an authorized person must establish the names of persons who were or might have been in contact with the confirmed case. An authorized person must trace and monitor all persons considered to be contacts with a confirmed case; all persons are subject to COVID-19 testing. Amendments to policy from 31 March, effective until 30 April, but with no changes for contact tracing.     See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

The first phase of vaccine rollout commenced on 19 March after receiving initial consignments of 100,000 Sinopharm doses on 16 March. Upon receiving 30,000 Covishield, vaccines, rollout of this vaccine commences 31 March.     The target populations include frontline health care workers, Community Health Workers, persons who are between 18 to 59 years, persons in close settings and those operating cross-border transportation, employees at Points of Entry, Police Officers, Journalists, members of the diplomatic corps, Mining and fishery sector employees, religious and traditional leaders, people with disability, minorities and refugees.     See the 26th Covid 19 Briefing by the Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185816/https://www.facebook.com/MoHSSNamibia/photos/pcb.723157175023955/723157085023964

Namibia started its vaccination campaign on March 23, 2021, after receiving donations of the Sinopharm vaccine from China (100,000 doses) and Covishield vaccine (30,000 doses) from India: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411140306/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Phase 1a (initial launch) Health workers at high to exceedingly high risk, older adults: 60 to 69 years old with at least one comorbidity and 70+ with no comorbidity and senior government officials and members of the diplomatic corps  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411141504/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/833096/8+AUGUST+2020+-+COVID19+UPDATE+-+150+NEW+CASES+-+65+NEW+RECOVERIES+-+MINISTRY+OF+HEALTH+AND+SOCIAL+SERVICES+-

While the ban on domestic and international flights have been lifted, operations have commenced with safety advisories in place. The NCDC continues to work with the Port Health Services, Nigeria Customs Service, and Nigeria Immigration Service to ensure enhanced surveillance at all points of entry.  Quarantine requirements  All new arrivals are expected to self-isolate at one location in the city of their arrival until the result of their second PCR test (which should be taken on day 7 of arrival) is known. If the second test is negative individuals can exit self-isolation from day 8 onwards. Anyone that has developed symptoms of coronavirus during their travel or later tests positive will be managed according to national guidelines for COVID-19 treatment. This may require quarantine at a government-monitored treatment centre.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426185006/https://covid19.ncdc.gov.ng/advisory/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426185154/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/entry-requirements

There is no debt or contract relief currently in place.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426192623/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Public spaces and services  Gatherings of over 50 people outside of work places are prohibited, including all weddings, conferences and sporting events. Bars, restaurants other than in hotels, events and recreational centres are currently closed. Places of worship are permitted to hold services, subject to limitations set by state authorities. On 21 December, the Nigerian Government announced that schools will remain closed until at least 18 January 2021.    Visits to public institutions, including government buildings, have been limited.    Additional measures include a mandatory requirement to wear face masks in public spaces.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426184149/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

Nigeria is currently registering people electronically for vaccination to ensure efficient and orderly scheduling of the date and time to receive the vaccine, Mr. Shuaib tells Africa Renewal. This is the first time Nigeria will pre-register people for vaccination.    All persons 18 years and above can register for the vaccination through an e-registration portal. The country relies on the media to promote this e-registration under an electronic immunization data management scheme.     The vaccination is then carried out in phases, according to predetermined classifications, Mr. Shuaib says. Frontline health workers are prioritized for the jab so they can safely care for others.    The primary health care agency uses its electronic database to track those who have received the first dose in order to know when they are due for their second dose.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426191848/https://www.un.org/africarenewal/magazine/april-2021/nigeria-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-kicks-africas-most-populous-country
No change in policy

Vaccinations will be free of charge and voluntary and are being delivered by Covax   The vaccination is expected to be done in phases. In the first phase, the vaccine will go to front-line workers in healthcare including but not limited to those working in treatment centres and Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This phase will also see the vaccination of people above 65 and those whose immunity is weak and is likely to easily be compromised like those with cancer, diabetes, HIV and other serious diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223001542/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2021/02/15/rwanda-begins-covid-19-vaccination-for-health-workers-others/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210128052530/https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/unpacking-rwanda-plan-distribute-covid-19-vaccine

The Health Emergency Committee in North Darfur state announced that eight deaths were recorded in the second wave of the Corona pandemic, while the number of cases during the past week reached 16, including three cases that were recorded on Monday.  Arabi announced his approval of the recommendations issued by the joint meeting of the State Security Committee and the Emergency Health Committee on Tuesday. The recommendations included strictly prohibiting gatherings and imposing penalties on those violating the precautionary measures.  https://archive.vn/XtNqa#selection-471.0-475.289  Dr Taha Badawi, reporter of the Supreme Chamber of Corona Crisis Management in Red Sea state, told Radio Dabanga that the state has issued a decision to postpone the diving festival in Muhammad Qul locality for a week until the situation was assessed.  https://archive.vn/XtNqa#selection-483.0-483.251

The government is still upholding the screening program for international travelers, requiring a negative PCR test result upon traveling to the country with additional testing to be done upon arrival. Any arriving traveler whose RDT test is positive will be isolated at a government-approved facility at his/her own expense. Travelers will remain at an approved facility until the PCR test is returned, with authorities holding their passports until the PCR test results have been received  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426083058/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/462621/sierra-leone-government-lifts-covid-19-state-of-public-health-emergency-and-curfew-as-of-late-march-update-19

Since the start of vaccine roll out by the Government of Sierra Leone back in March 15 2021 the country has come a long way. More than 40 thousand people have received their first dose of the vaccine by starting with politicians to advocate for the vaccination, to key workers and  elderly groups beginning form march 22, 2021. Now the national COVID 19 emergency response center (NaCOVERc) has put on a press release on their official website posted on April 11 announcing that the Vaccination is available for all people above the age of 40 years. i have archived two of those press release, the first showing the initial roll out schedule and the second archive (week 14 bulletin) showing the the New post on the second page of the link.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210412204415/http://dhse.gov.sl/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/PUBLIC-NOTICE-COVID-19-VACCINES-ROLLOUT.pdf      https://web.archive.org/web/20210426064750/http://dhse.gov.sl/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/National-Week-14-bulletin-2021-1.pdf

It is difficult to find official information on the state of education provision in Somalia. Reports from 21 March (https://archive.vn/QO6uw) indicated that schools would be closed until April 3rd, and there is no evidence that the policy was extended after that date.     Reuters data indicates that there are no school closure policies in effect - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425172500/https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/somalia/    Anecdotal evidence such as https://web.archive.org/web/20210425173846/https://twitter.com/FENPS04/status/1380423418475122690 indicates that schools are open.

A news report indicates that ""schools have reportedly re-opened"" following the two week closure implemented on 21 March  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425174345/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466141/somalia-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-april-12-by-comparison-with-those-in-effect-in-mid-february-update-11
No policy change found - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425174719/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/somalia/coronavirus

No policy change found. The IMF reports that since March 2021, the government has instituted a ""suspension of public gathering and at least a 2-meter social distance to be observed by people attending permitted meetings;"", and that ""weddings and special parties are suspended"" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425181838/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change, the US Embassy in Somalia reports that public transportation is operating normally. https://web.archive.org/web/20210425180919/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A night-time curfew is in place https://web.archive.org/web/20210425174719/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/somalia/coronavirus and the Ministry of Health recommends that people stay at home - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425183618/https://moh.nomadilab.org/2020/04/11/how-often-should-you-visit-your-midwife/
The US Embassy in Somalia reports no restrictions on internal movement - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425180919/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy. The US Embassy in Somalia reports that a negative COVID-19 test taken within 96 hours of travel is required to enter Somalia. Screening is under the guidance of UN and World Health Organization representatives in Mogadishu. Aden Adde International Airport (Mogadishu) and Egal International Airport (Hargeisa) have put in place additional measures to screen passengers arriving at Hargeisa by air, including temperature checks. All passengers must wear face masks. U.S. citizens arriving in Somaliland are required to self-isolate for 14 days after arrival if they do not have a negative COVID-19 test and will be quarantined at a government-appointed facility at their own expense. Somali authorities established a quarantine unit at Aden Adde International Airport to isolate passengers who demonstrate symptoms of coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425180919/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    ""Land borders between Somaliland and Djibouti have reopened, and the Port of Berbera is operational"" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425174345/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466141/somalia-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-april-12-by-comparison-with-those-in-effect-in-mid-february-update-11

No change, the IMF reports that ""In response to the second wave of the virus, tax relief on core basic food commodities (rice, cooking oil, flour, dates, etc.) was reinstated from March 2021"" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425181838/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change found, a public telephone health line dedicated to Covid-19 questions is available - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425183618/https://moh.nomadilab.org/2020/04/11/how-often-should-you-visit-your-midwife/

The US Embassy in Somalia reports that testing ""is available at the country’s major medical facilities (Digfeer Hospital, Medipark Diagnostics, Sahal Transit Transportation Clinic, Dur-Dur Clinic, Aden Adde International Airport Clinic, and other private hospitals).  The charge for the test is approximately USD 30 (SOS 17,500)."" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425180919/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence of changes to contact tracing found - https://web.archive.org/web/20210425180919/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
